awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Small: Usable Key Management and Forward Secrecy for Secure Email
awd_abstract_narration:
Sending and receiving information securely online is a basic need in our connected world. However, one of the most frequently used online applications, email, remains largely insecure for all but the most expert users. The researchers will gather data to better understand why users do not adopt secure email. They will also identify the most practical, usable practices for users to safeguard their secure email from hackers, and make sure they do not lose access to their secure email by forgetting the password or key that unlocks their sensitive emails. The initial studies will be conducted in a laboratory environment, utilizing a novel methodology the researchers have developed that tests whether two novice users can adopt a secure email system without help from an outside expert. Toward the end of the project, the researchers will conduct long-term usability studies with the best-of-class systems they have developed to understand how people integrate secure email into their everyday email habits.

This project addresses the long-standing problem of providing usable, secure email for the general public. Key management is a core problem. The researchers will explore a trust-on-first-use (TOFU) key exchange, followed by a variety of methods that improve trust in the exchanged keys. Starting with TOFU key exchange prioritizes deployability and usability, while additional methods can increase security, for example, by using a public ledger and forward secrecy. Keys will be exchanged only with regular or approved contacts so that it is not easy for spammers to deliver encrypted spam and malware to large numbers of users. The researchers will also develop usable key storage software, including key portability and backup. Potential solutions include purely local storage, encrypted cloud storage, a smartphone app, and hardware tokens. For backup, we will evaluate a variety of methods to help users store a master key in a secure location, without requiring technical expertise to manage the key. The researchers will support forward secrecy for secure email using key ratcheting. By developing for email, with its generality and interoperability requirements, advances in usable key management will be broadly applicable to a wide variety of other applications, including instant messaging.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award focused on improving the security and usability of key management for secure communication and authentication.

Secure Communication

Secure email provides privacy, but adoption is low. To better understand this situation, we helped create a stakeholder model showing how the tussle among stakeholders explains the evolution of fragmented solutions undertaken by industry, academia, and independent developers. Our analysis underscores the unlikelihood of a universal solution. Current solutions are inadequate for vulnerable users, and although secure messaging is complementary, it cannot fully substitute secure email technology.

We interviewed individuals who use a secure email service to understand their motivations. The findings revealed that the primary reasons behind adoption were distrust towards large tech companies, a dislike of targeted advertising, and a strong desire for privacy. Participants expressed concerns about the surveillance economy and felt threatened by it. Our research suggests that providers have an opportunity to enhance privacy protection by offering interoperable services and attracting more users based on the privacy benefits they provide. 

Billions of users use secure messaging apps like WhatsApp to exchange encrypted messages. The security of these systems relies in part on users verifying that they have the correct encryption key of their communication partners. This verification process, known as the authentication ceremony, often involves scanning a QR code or manually comparing keys through a phone call. Our research helped establish that most people find the authentication ceremony fundamentally unusable. We extensively redesigned the authentication ceremony, prioritizing comprehension over compliance. Lab studies demonstrate that our design increased comprehension relative to the existing design. Our work demonstrates that careful design can empower users to make more informed decisions about verifying their privacy guarantees.

We investigated the automation of the authentication ceremony in secure messaging apps, aiming to relieve users of this burden. We demonstrated the feasibility of attackers deceiving users with fake keys, granting them access to encrypted messages. To address this vulnerability, we devised three automated defenses, each accompanied by a rigorous security analysis outlining their effectiveness against specific attacks. These findings offer insights for providers enhancing their systems to offer users automated privacy assurances.

In secure messaging systems, deniability is a fundamental property allowing users to deny sending a message since the other party could have forged it. We conducted one of the first studies of user perceptions and understanding of deniability. The results reveal that users struggle to comprehend the concept as explained by experts. Notably, users strongly favor non-repudiation over deniability, raising questions about what should be the default property in these systems. Furthermore, the legal aspect of deniability remains untested in US court cases. Our research raises fundamental questions surrounding this topic that need exploring.

We created two innovative systems for end-to-end encryption: MessageGuard for website-independent encryption in the browser and InfoGuard for application-independent encryption in the operating system. Both systems automate key management and provide scalable solutions to significantly increase encryption adoption by implementing it at the system level rather than within applications.

Authentication

Password replacements, such as two-factor authentication (2FA), have struggled due to challenges balancing usability, deployability, and security. We conducted one of the first long-term studies comparing multiple 2FA methods and surveyed the BYU community after rolling out 2FA. Our studies show that one-third of the participants reported not having their second-factor device immediately available when they needed it, and half of the participants experienced account lockout. Users prefer fewer 2FA logins for less-sensitive accounts. Our work demonstrates recurring design flaws in the setup process. We designed and analyzed a 2FA manager that simplifies user interactions with 2FA systems, similar to how a password manager simplifies interactions with passwords.

Hardware security keys are a proposed password replacement. We were the first to identify their drawbacks, including difficulties with registration, cumbersome account recovery, the potential for authenticator bloat, and several privacy concerns. We developed similar cryptographic methods to overcome some flaws using a cloud-based authentication service to manage users? keys. The system provides automated and secure login, with simple account recovery and unlinkability. This work demonstrated a usable way to provide passwordless login before the announcement of Passkeys, which offers similar benefits.

A longstanding challenge with certificate-based authentication is effective certificate revocation. We developed new global and organization-level revocation methods that scale better than existing approaches. 

We developed a secure approach to maintaining a constant length for primary passwords in password managers and crypto wallets in the face of exponential growth in computer speeds. The design retains security without sacrificing usability.

Broader Impacts

The project involved extensive student participation, with 29 undergraduate and 11 graduate students, including seven females. The research experience motivated some students to pursue graduate degrees. Notably, an undergraduate student was the first author of a groundbreaking certificate revocation approach, and presented the paper at NDSS 2000.
